questions.text: Which of the following statements about selenocysteine and Pyrrolysine is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Pyrrolysine is incorporated into proteins at UGA codons with the help of a specific tRNA.

options.label: B
options.text: The incorporation of selenocysteine requires a special mRNA structure known as the selenocysteine insertion sequence (SECIS).

options.label: C
options.text: Selenocysteine is synthesized from cysteine during protein translation.

options.label: D
options.text: Pyrrolysine is only found in eukaryotic organisms and not in prokaryotes.

questions.correct_answer: B. The incorporation of selenocysteine requires a special mRNA structure known as the selenocysteine insertion sequence (SECIS).

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes the metabolic fate of specific amino acids?

options.label: A
options.text: All amino acids can be classified as either glucogenic or ketogenic without exceptions.

options.label: B
options.text: Aspartate is a purely ketogenic amino acid.

options.label: C
options.text: Phenylalanine can be converted to both glucose and ketone bodies.

questions.correct_answer: C. Phenylalanine can be converted to both glucose and ketone bodies.
questions.explanation:
Type

Definition

 Examples:

Purely Glucogenic

Amino acids that are converted into pyruvate or TCA cycle intermediates (e.g., oxaloacetate, α-ketoglutarate) and contribute to glucose synthesis via gluconeogenesis.

 Aspartate, Alanine, Glycine, Serine, Cysteine

Purely Ketogenic

Amino acids that yield only acetyl-CoA or acetoacetate, leading to the formation of ketone bodies.

 Leucine, Lysine

Both Glucogenic & Ketogenic

Amino acids that can be converted into both glucose and ketone bodies, contributing to energy metabolism through multiple pathways.

 Phenylalanine, Tyrosine, Tryptophan, Isoleucine, Threonine

questions.text: An athlete undergoing high-altitude training adapts to decreased oxygen availability by altering haemoglobin to enhance oxygen delivery. Which structural form of haemoglobin is predominantly favoured to enhance oxygen release to tissues?
questions.explanation:
Structural Form Description Effect on Oxygen Binding
Taut (T) form Low oxygen affinity, stabilized by CO₂, H⁺, and 2,3-BPG Favours oxygen release to tissues
Relaxed (R) form High oxygen affinity, stabilized by oxygen binding Favours oxygen uptake in lungs

questions.text: Which of the following techniques is most widely used to estimate a patient's HbA1c level for monitoring long-term glucose control?
questions.explanation:
Types of Chromatography

Description

Cation exchange chromatography

(Option A)
  • Carboxymethyl sepharose is a widely used example of cation exchange chromatography, which is commonly employed for HbA1c estimation.
  • This technique separates positively charged (cationic) molecules using an anionic stationary phase.
  • Initially, the protein mixture is held in the stationary phase to allow impurities to be removed.
  • Once all the impurities are removed, a technique known as elution is used upon the stationary phase to derive the desired result.

In this, positively charged proteins bind to the negatively charged stationary phase.

Anion exchange chromatography

(Option B)
  • It is used to separate proteins with a negative charge.
  • The stationary phase consists of cationic groups, such as quaternary ammonium groups.
  • This method retains anions while allowing other components to pass through.

Gel filtration chromatography (Option C)
  • Also known as size exclusion chromatography, this technique separates proteins based on their size.
  • Smaller proteins get trapped in the pores of the gel matrix, slowing their movement, while larger proteins move quickly through the column.

Paper chromatography (Option D)
  • It is a type of planar chromatography conducted on a flat surface.
  • This method separates amino acids based on their polarity.
  • Nonpolar amino acids move faster, while polar amino acids stay closer to the application point.

questions.text: Based on which characteristic the technique SDS-PAGE is used to separate proteins?
The electrophoresis pattern in the image shows a prominent alpha-2 band. Which disease is most likely associated with this finding?
questions.explanation:
Disorder

EPP Pattern

Multiple Myeloma

(Option B)
  • It is characterised by a narrow and intense band in the gamma region, the M band.
  • This band indicates the presence of a monoclonal protein (M protein), which is a hallmark of multiple myeloma.

Nephrotic syndrome

(Option A)
  • It shows a relative prominence of the alpha-2 band.
  • This pattern results from the selective loss of smaller proteins, such as albumin, in the urine while larger proteins, such as alpha-2 macroglobulin, remain in the blood.

Decompensated chronic liver disease (DCLD)

(Option C)

It exhibits beta-gamma bridging. This occurs due to polyclonal immunoglobulin production, leading to a continuous smear between the beta and gamma regions.

questions.text: A laboratory technician prepares samples for electrophoresis as the person is suspected to auffer from multiple myeloma. Which sample type is preferred for this test to ensure accurate results?

A 39-year-old male complains of unexplained fatigue and joint pain and visits his physician. The physician suspects chronic inflammatory disease and advises serum protein electrophoresis, which shows an increase in alpha 2 bands. Which of the following proteins shows an increase in alpha 2 bands?
questions.explanation:
Electrophoresis band

Proteins

Albumin band

Albumin (Option A ruled out)

Alpha 1 band

Alpha 1 antitrypsin,alpha-fetoprotein, transthyretin

Alpha 2 band

Macroglobulin (Option B), haptoglobin, ceruloplasmin

Beta band

Transferrin (Option D ), low-density lipoproteins

Gamma band

Gamma immunoglobulin (Option C),fibrinogen

questions.text: Which protein migrates the farthest from the application point towards the anode in serum protein electrophoresis?
questions.explanation:
Protein Fraction Charge Migration Distance (From Cathode to Anode)
Albumin Most negative Farthest migration
Alpha-1 globulin (Option C ruled out) Less negative Closer to origin
Alpha-2 globulin Less negative Closer to origin
Beta globulin (Option D ruled out) Intermediate Closer to albumin
Gamma globulin (Option B ruled out) Least negative Closest to the cathode

questions.text: All the following factors determine the mobility of proteins in electrophoresis except?
What is the most likely cause of the rightward shift of the oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve?
questions.explanation:
Factor Shifts Curve to the Right (↓ O2 Affinity, ↑ O2 Release) Shifts Curve to the Left (↑ O2 Affinity, ↓ O2 Release)
pH (Bohr Effect) Decreased pH (Acidosis) Increased pH (Alkalosis) (Option C ruled out)
Carbon Dioxide (CO₂) Increased CO₂ (Hypercapnia) Decreased CO₂ (Hypocapnia) (Option B ruled out)
Temperature Increased temperature (e.g., fever, exercise) Decreased temperature (e.g., hypothermia)
2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG) Increased 2,3-BPG (e.g., chronic hypoxia, anemia) Decreased 2,3-BPG (Option A ruled out)
Carbon Monoxide (CO) - Presence of CO (Increased oxygen affinity, prevents release)
Fetal Hemoglobin (HbF) - Presence of HbF (Higher oxygen affinity)
Exercise Increased exercise -
Altitude Acclimatization to high altitude -
Growth Hormone Increases O₂ release (Shifts right) -
Thyroxine (T₄) Increases O₂ release (Shifts right) -

questions.text: A newborn is diagnosed with a condition where their haemoglobin has an unusually high affinity for oxygen. What is the physiological basis for the increased oxygen affinity of fetal haemoglobin compared to adult haemoglobin?

options.label: B
options.text: HbF contains serine that reduces the positive charge of the globin side chain.

options.label: C
options.text: Higher histidine content, reducing oxygen affinity.

options.label: D
options.text: Binds oxygen more loosely than adult Hb

questions.correct_answer: B. HbF contains serine that reduces the positive charge of the globin side chain.
questions.explanation:
Feature

Adult Hemoglobin (HbA)

Fetal Hemoglobin (HbF)

Globin Side Chains

α₂β₂

α₂γ₂

Oxygen Affinity

Lower

Higher

2,3-BPG Binding

Higher

Lower

Physiological Role

Tissue oxygen delivery

Oxygen extraction from maternal blood

Charge in Central Cavity

More positive

Less positive

pH Sensitivity

More sensitive

Less sensitive

questions.text: A patient with anaemia has elevated levels of 2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG) in their red blood cells. How does this increased 2,3-BPG level affect the patient’s haemoglobin in terms of oxygen delivery?

options.label: A
options.text: Forms salt bridges with positively charged residues forming a relaxed structure

options.label: B
options.text: Disrupts salt bridges formed in the taut structure, decreasing oxygen affinity

options.label: C
options.text: Forms salt bridges with positively charged residues stabilising taut structure

options.label: D
options.text: Binds to the heme directly, decreasing the oxygen affinity

questions.correct_answer: C. Forms salt bridges with positively charged residues stabilising taut structure

questions.text: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding pKa and its implications in biochemistry?

options.label: A
options.text: The lower the pKa of the amino group, the weaker the acid.

options.label: B
options.text: pKa remains constant and does not change with the medium.

options.label: C
options.text: The net charge of a protein does not depend on the pKa value of the functional group.

options.label: D
options.text: When pH =pKa +/- 1, substances act as buffers.

questions.correct_answer: D. When pH =pKa +/- 1, substances act as buffers.
questions.explanation:
Concept Explanation
Definition pKa is the pH at which 50% of a molecule is ionized.
Buffering Capacity Maximum when pH ≈ pKa ±1.
Amino Acids & Proteins Ionization of functional groups depends on pKa, affecting protein charge and structure.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the role of histidine residues in myoglobin in relation to carbon monoxide (CO) binding?

options.label: A
options.text: Prevent CO binding by increasing the heme's affinity for oxygen.

options.label: B
options.text: Enhance CO binding, similar to oxygen.

options.label: C
options.text: Inhibit CO binding by sterically hindering the heme iron.

options.label: D
options.text: It does not influence the binding of CO to the heme.

questions.correct_answer: C. Inhibit CO binding by sterically hindering the heme iron.

questions.text: Which cellular component is primarily responsible for degrading intracellular proteins tagged with ubiquitin?
Which protein assists in proper folding by binding to hydrophobic regions of other proteins during the folding process?
questions.explanation:
Function Chaperonin Action
Prevents misfolding Shields hydrophobic regions to avoid aggregation
Assists refolding Helps denatured proteins regain functional shape
Provides an isolated chamber Forms a cavity where proteins fold properly
ATP-dependent process Uses ATP to facilitate conformational changes

questions.text: Which of the following techniques provides the highest resolution for determining the primary structure of proteins?
questions.explanation:
Structure

Methods of Determination

Primary

  • Edman sequencing
  • Sanger’s sequencing (Option C)
  • Reverse sequencing

Secondary

  • Optical rotatory dispersion (Option D)
  • Ocular dichroism

Tertiary

  • X-ray crystallography (Option B)
  • UV Spectroscopy
  • NMR spectroscopy (Option A)

Quaternary
  • SDS PAGE (Sodium Dodecyl Sulfate-Polyacrylamide Gel Electrophoresis)

questions.text: What type of bond is primarily responsible for stabilising the structure in proteins as shown in the image?

options.label: B
options.text: Ionic bonds between charged amino acids

questions.correct_answer: C. Hydrogen bonds between backbone atoms
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Alpha Helix

Beta-Pleated Sheet

Shape

Spiral or coiled structure

Extended, zigzag structure, pleated

Hydrogen bonding

Within the same strand (intrastrand)

Between different strands (interstrand)

Compactness

More compact

Less compact, more extended

Stability

Stabilised by internal H-bonds

Stabilised by H-bonds between strands

Flexibility

More flexible

Less flexible, more rigid

Examples

Keratin, Myoglobin

Silk fibroin, immunoglobulins

questions.text: Which of the following interactions is primarily responsible for maintaining the structure of proteins, as shown in the image?
questions.explanation:
Protein Structure

Linkage

Primary Structure: Linear sequence of amino acids encoded by mRNA.

 

Peptide bonds (Covalent, via dehydration reaction) (Option A)

Secondary structure: Local folding into α-helices & β-sheets due to backbone interactions and is of two types:

  • Alpha-helix
  • Beta-pleated sheet

 

Hydrogen bonds (Between carbonyl and amide groups) (Option B)

Tertiary structure: Three-dimensional structure of a single polypeptide due to side-chain interactions.

 

 Disulfide bonds (Option C) (Covalent), Hydrophobic interactions, Hydrogen bonds, Ionic bonds, Van der Waals forces

Quaternary structure: Assembly of multiple polypeptide subunits into a functional protein

 

 Non-covalent interactions (Hydrogen bonds, Ionic bonds, Hydrophobic interactions, Van der Waals forces); Rarely Disulfide bonds

questions.text: Match the following protein tests with their primary purpose or detection target: 1.Ninhydrin test a. Detects compouds containing 2 or more peptide bonds 2.Xanthoproteic test b. Detects aromatic amino acids 3.Sakaguchi test c. Detects arginine 4.Biuret test d. Detects alpha-amino acids
questions.explanation:
Test Principle Detection Target Positive Result
Biuret Test Peptide bonds react with Cu²⁺ in an alkaline medium Peptide bonds (proteins and polypeptides) Violet color
Ninhydrin Test Ninhydrin reacts with free α-amino groups Free amino acids and proteins with free NH₂ Blue/Purple color
Xanthoproteic Test Nitration of aromatic rings with HNO₃ Aromatic amino acids (tyrosine, tryptophan, phenylalanine) Yellow color
Sakaguchi Test Reaction of α-naphthol with guanidino group in the presence of NaOBr Arginine Red color
Lead Acetate Test Reaction of sulfur-containing amino acids with lead acetate Sulfur-containing amino acids (cysteine, methionine) Black precipitate
Hopkins-Cole Test Reaction of tryptophan with glyoxylic acid in a strong acid medium Tryptophan Violet ring
Millon's Test Reaction of phenol groups with mercuric nitrate in acidic medium Tyrosine Red color
Folin-Ciocalteu Test Phenolic groups react with phosphomolybdic-phosphotungstic acid Tyrosine & Tryptophan Blue color
Nitroprusside Test Reaction of cysteine with sodium nitroprusside Cysteine Red color
Heller’s Test Proteins get precipitated by strong acids Proteins (albumins and globulins) White precipitate
Test for Casein Acid precipitation of casein Casein (milk protein) White precipitate

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the properties of glycine?
questions.explanation:
Property Glycine Other Amino Acids
Chirality Achiral Chiral (except glycine)
Stereoisomerism Absent Present (D & L forms)
Optical Activity None Optically active
Asymmetrical Carbon No Yes

Property Description
Simplest Amino Acid Has two hydrogen atoms attached to the α-carbon.
Polarity Non-polar; fits into both hydrophilic and hydrophobic environments due to its small size.
Chirality Lacks a chiral center, making it optically inactive and incapable of stereoisomerism.
Glycine Cleavage System Produces ammonia (NH₃), carbon dioxide (CO₂), and N,N-methylene tetrahydrofolate.
Biosynthetic Role Precursor for porphyrins, creatine, glutathione, serine, purines, and heme.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with complaints of chronic fatigue and frequent infections. She follows a strict vegetarian diet and consumes less protein-rich food. Laboratory tests reveal a decreased level of a particular amino acid. Which of the following amino acids is likely deficient in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Amino Acid Function Dietary Sources Deficiency Effects
Threonine Immune function, collagen formation, protein synthesis Meat, dairy, eggs, legumes Impaired immune response, fatigue
Lysine Protein synthesis, enzyme function, calcium absorption Meat, fish, dairy, legumes Poor wound healing, frequent infections, fatigue
Tryptophan (Option B) Precursor for serotonin and niacin (B3) Dairy, turkey, nuts, seeds Mood disturbances, pellagra (niacin deficiency)
Methionine (Option D) Precursor for S-adenosylmethionine (SAM), involved in methylation reactions Meat, eggs, dairy Fatty liver, slow growth
Phenylalanine Precursor for tyrosine, neurotransmitters (dopamine, norepinephrine) Meat, dairy, soy, fish Growth retardation, mental impairment
Leucine Muscle protein synthesis, energy production Meat, dairy, eggs, soybeans Muscle wasting, hypoglycemia
Isoleucine Muscle metabolism, hemoglobin formation Meat, fish, eggs, soy Muscle weakness, dizziness
Valine Muscle growth, tissue repair Meat, dairy, legumes Neurological symptoms, muscle weakness
Histidine Precursor for histamine, important in immune function Meat, poultry, fish, dairy Anemia, impaired immunity
Amino Acid Function Synthesized From Deficiency Effects
Tyrosine (Option B ruled out) Precursor for neurotransmitters, thyroid hormones Phenylalanine Rare deficiency, linked to metabolic disorders
Cysteine (Option D ruled out) Antioxidant defense (glutathione synthesis) Methionine Rare deficiency, oxidative stress
Alanine (Option C ruled out) Gluconeogenesis, nitrogen transport Pyruvate No significant deficiency
Glycine (Option C ruled out) Collagen synthesis, neurotransmission Serine No significant deficiency
Serine Phospholipid synthesis, neurotransmission 3-Phosphoglycerate No significant deficiency
Aspartate Urea cycle, TCA cycle Oxaloacetate No significant deficiency
Asparagine Protein synthesis, nitrogen metabolism Aspartate No significant deficiency
Glutamate Neurotransmitter, precursor for GABA α-Ketoglutarate No significant deficiency
Proline Collagen synthesis, wound healing Glutamate No significant deficiency

Amino Acid Function Synthesized From Deficiency Effects
Arginine Nitric oxide production, wound healing Glutamate Poor wound healing, immune dysfunction
Glutamine Nitrogen transport, immune function Glutamate Muscle wasting, immune dysfunction

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids contains a hydroxyl group (OH) in its side chain?
questions.explanation:
Category Amino Acids Functional Group Properties
Hydroxyl (-OH) group Serine, Threonine, Tyrosine Hydroxyl (-OH) Polar, involved in hydrogen bonding and phosphorylation.
Sulfur-containing Cysteine (Option B ruled out), Methionine Thiol (-SH), Thioether (-S-) Cysteine forms disulfide bonds; Methionine is involved in methyl transfer reactions.
Aromatic Phenylalanine (Option A ruled out), Tyrosine, Tryptophan Benzene or Indole rings Hydrophobic, absorb UV light, involved in protein-protein interactions.
Amide (-CONH₂) group Asparagine, Glutamine (Option D ruled out) Amide (-CONH₂) Polar, involved in hydrogen bonding.
Carboxyl (-COOH) group (Acidic) Aspartic acid, Glutamic acid Carboxyl (-COOH) Negatively charged at physiological pH, important in enzyme active sites.
Amino (-NH₃⁺) group (Basic) Lysine, Arginine, Histidine Amine (-NH₂, -C=NH, -NH⁺) Positively charged at physiological pH, involved in salt bridge formation.
Aliphatic (Non-polar hydrocarbon chains) Glycine, Alanine, Valine, Leucine, Isoleucine, Proline Hydrocarbon (-CH, -CH₂, -CH₃) Hydrophobic, contribute to protein stability.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic of the isoelectric pH (pI) of a protein?
questions.explanation:
Characteristic Explanation
No net charge At pI, the total positive and negative charges on the protein cancel each other out.
Minimal mobility Since the protein has no net charge, it does not migrate in an electric field.
Low buffering capacity Buffers work best when pH ≠ pI; at pI, there is minimal change in charge per unit of pH change.
Low solubility Electrostatic repulsion is minimal at pI, promoting aggregation and precipitation.
